5.text:
I'm not sure what I expected to find when
I went to Chernobyl. I mean it's been so long

9.text:
since the nuclear reactor there melted down
and spewed radioactive atoms across the land.

16.text:
So for almost thirty years this place has
been virtually abandoned. These days workers

23.text:
are allowed into the zone but only for two
weeks at a time. And that's not because the

29.text:
levels of radiation are too high, it's actually
for psychological reasons. More than two weeks

34.text:
in a place like this will apparently make
you think strange things. And I was only here

41.text:
for four days but I started to think about
rocks.

50.text:
Rocks appear to be permanent. I mean I know
that they aren't. Mountains are constantly

56.text:
eroding
and in places the crust is melting back into

60.text:
the mantle. Rock obviously isn't permanent
but on the scale of a human life, it is and

69.text:
people recognized that fact - rocks are permanent
- for thousands of years and I think that's

76.text:
what makes them important to us. I mean, "a
diamond is forever"

81.text:
We build these monuments out of rock because
they will outlast us and virtually every other

88.text:
material we can think of. Our modern structures
of metal and glass are just rock refined by

94.text:
our ingenuity. Rocks are both practical and
symbolic. We seek to indentify ourselves with

102.text:
rocks. We carve our heroes in stone because
we want them to last forever and there's a

109.text:
way in which we want that kind of permanence
for ourselves too. I think it's in the core

114.text:
of the desire to scratch our name into stone,
put your initials in wet cement, really man-made

120.text:
rock, or fasten a padlock to a bridge. In
this way we try to push our impermanence from

127.text:
our minds. The monuments, statues and bridges,
they give us a sense of continuity, stability.

133.text:
That this is the way it is and the way it's
always been. Like the way we first we concieved

140.text:
of stars: static, unchanging, eternal. And
this way of viewing the world helps us maintain

149.text:
our greatest delusion: the thought that we
are in any way eternal. We want to believe

158.text:
that some part of us, our consciousness or
our soul will last forever. But what do you

166.text:
make of it then when you see stone is not even
so permanent?

171.text:
Walking around Chernobyl I think it's understandable
I started contemplating not only the permanence

176.text:
of rocks but also their decay, and by extension,
our decay, death, what the world would look

185.text:
You know the closest I can come to imagining
true nothingness is to picture the universe

194.text:
running really fast in reverse. All the galaxies
squeezing closer together, stars expanding

201.text:
back into gas clouds and everything getting
hotter and denser, compactifying until the

205.text:
whole observable universe could fit into a
room and then sinking further into a tiny

211.text:
point and then... nothing. Not the nothingness
of empty space but real nothingess which has

220.text:
no size and no time. To me that is probably
what death looks like, a nothiness so complete

229.text:
you wouldn't even miss it. For that, you'd
have to be there. But just as soon as I can

236.text:
form this thought, it evaporates like a void
in nature. The world rushes in to fill it.

243.text:
And this make sense because the hardware I'm
running has been developed over billions of

248.text:
years with the only requriement being that
it frequently and accurately makes copies

252.text:
of itself and it would help not in the slightest
in the goal of making copies if the hardware

257.text:
could accurately simulate its own non-existence.
When we do acknowledge our impermanence, it

264.text:
is often through insipid catch phrases like
"yolo" or it's in art projects like Damien

272.text:
Hirst's "The physical impossibility of death
in the mind of someone living", which is just

278.text:
a huge shark in a tank of formaldehyde. A
sense of our mortality should strike fear

283.text:
into us, like the sense I have when I'm swimming
hundreds of meters off shore and the water

288.text:
below is deep and dark and I can picture the
shark swimming beneath me. The same kind of

297.text:
fate stalks us daily but not in this visceral
way, just in trivial ignorable way. Hence

305.text:
the delusion. You're permanent like stone,
always were and always will be. So we are

313.text:
left hardwired for denial, a selected inability
to imagine true nothingness, an ephemeral

320.text:
sack of particles that thinks itself
eternal. This delusion is comforting and it

327.text:
makes living easier. It might drive you crazy
to be confronted with the ultimate meaninglessness

332.text:
of everything all the time, what we call nihilism.
But the same delusion I'd argue is also debilitating.

341.text:
It lulls you into a false sense of security,
inaction, like a due date a long time in the

347.text:
future. There's always tomorrow so we procrastinate
living the life we truly desire and we live

355.text:
in more fear. The sense that your soul is
eternal makes you cowardly because failure

362.text:
would stick with you forever. For really ever.
Shame, embarassment, disappointment, they

370.text:
would never leave you. A distant horizon encourages
you to play it safe. Live to fight another

376.text:
day, for after all there is always another
day. And this is why I find nihilism liberating

386.text:
and emboldening. If you can really picture
the nothingess that awaits you then what is

392.text:
there to be afraid of? Errors and humiliations
will be forgotten but great achiements may

400.text:
not. We may have no meaning in the cosmic
context of the universe but we make our own

407.text:
meaning daily with each other and this is
the thought that leads to action: your days

413.text:
are numbered, you don't know what that number
is but it's finite, so get busy with what

418.text: it is you want to do. Time is running out.
